stanza.l: We trekked into a far country,
Our deeper content was never spoken,
But each knew all the other said.
He told me how calm his soul was laid
By the lack of anvil and strife.
“The wooing kestrel,” I said, “mutes his mating-note
To please the harmony of this sweet silence.”
And when at the day’s end
And the air fleeced its particles for a coverlet;
When star after star came out

l.figLang: To guard their lovers in oblivion

stanza.l: My soul so leapt that my evening prayer
